questions.text: The egg shown in the given image is recovered from the perianal region using the scotch tape technique. Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
The egg shown in the given image is that of Enterobius vermicularis.

The eggs of E. vermicularis are plano-convex in shape, have a double-layered outer shell, and are approximately 50–60 μm in length. Infectious larvae, which are tadpole-shaped, are often visible inside the egg. Unlike those of other intestinal nematodes, these eggs are not found in the stools. The female worm lays eggs in the perianal region.

The eggs are recovered using the scotch tape technique in the morning before a bowel movement. Transparent scotch tape is applied directly to the perianal area and then placed on a microscope slide for examination.

Other options: 

Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are large, broadly oval, with thick mammillated shell, and are typically stained golden brown with bile.

Ancylostoma duodenale eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Strongyloides stercoralis eggs hatch within the mucosa of the small intestine forming rhabditiform larvae. These larvae are passed in the stools, not the eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: The image below depicts the structure of the HIV virus. Which of the following genes determines the core and shell of the viral structure?
questions.solution:
The given image is the structure of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and the gag gene determines the core and shell of the HIV virus.

It is expressed as a precursor protein, p55. This precursor protein is cleaved into three proteins, p15, p18 and p24, which make up the viral core and shell. The major core antigen is p24 which can be detected in serum during the early stages of HIV infection before antibodies appear.

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

Structural genes are the genes coding for structural proteins. They are

  • Gag gene: Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
  • Env gene: Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
  • Pol gene: Codes for the enzymes polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease

Non-structural and regulatory genes:

  • tat: Trans-activating gene
  • nef: Negative factor gene
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene
  • vif: Viral infectivity factor gene
  • vpu: (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
  • vpr: Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
  • LTR: Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text:
A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions, as shown in the image below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. The hair shaft showed ectothrix, but the nails were spared. Which of the following is likely to be the cause of this condition?

KOH - Potassium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the involvement of the hair and skin but not the nails along with the microscopic examination findings point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing, which is seen in dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichophyton: Infection involves the skin, hair, and nails. The species include Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton schoenleinii, and Trichophyton violaceu. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum: Infection involves skin and hair. The species include Microsporum gypseum, Microsporum canis, and Microsporum nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton: Infection involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia. Epidermophyton floccosum is the only species in this genus.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellophane tape (cellophane tape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Endothrix refers to dermatophyte infections of the hair that invade the hair shaft and internalize into the hair cell. As the name suggests, endothrix causes infection inside the hair shaft and ectothrix causes infection outside the shaft.

  • T. tonsurans, T. violaceum, T. schoenleinii, Trichophyton yaoundei, and Trichophyton soudanense cause endothrix type of tinea capitis.
    • Remember: TV is always kept inside the house (ENDO) — so T. tonsurans and T. violaceum cause endothrix.
  • Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.

Sporothrix does not cause superficial mycoses.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail which is characteristic of Brugia malayi.

Brugia malayi is endemic to Kerala (most common), Assam, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and West Bengal.

Brugia malayi are smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti. It shows kinks and secondary curves. Cephalic space is longer and carries double stylets at the anterior end. The nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films. The tip of the tail carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Other options:

Option A: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

Option C: The microfilariae of Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Option D: The microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus is unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male from West Bengal presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Sandfly was found to be the vector for his condition. Which of the following morphological form(s) is/are not seen in the causative organism ?
  1. Epimastigote
  2. Promastigote
  3. Trypomastigote
  4. Amastigote
questions.solution:
1 and 3 morphological forms are not seen(Option-C). The given clinical finding is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by Sandfly bite. Epimastigote and Trypomastigote forms are not seen in Leishmania.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

  • Amastigote form: in humans and other mammals
  • Promastigote form: in the sandfly and artificial culture

The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man.

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

Amastigote form: It is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is intracellular, found inside macrophages, monocytes or reticuloendothelial cells. A kinetoplast is present which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form: It is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. Kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

The lifecycle of Leishmania is shown below.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male patient diagnosed with malaria was commenced on an anti-malarial drug. After two days, port wine-colored urine was noted. His lab reports are given below. What is your diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9.0 g/dL
Blood glucose - 100 mg/dL
Serum creatinine - 5.6 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with malaria treated with an anti-malarial drug (likely quinine) developing hemoglobinuria (port-wine stained urine), hemolysis (reduced hemoglobin), and renal failure (increased creatinine) is suggestive of blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever (malarial hemoglobinuria) is an autoimmune process seen in Falciparum malaria, particularly in patients who have experienced repeated past infections and inadequate treatment with quinine. Clinical manifestations include fever, prostration, hemoglobinuria, and bilious vomiting, with the passage of dark red or blackish urine. 

It is due to massive intravascular hemolysis caused by anti-erythrocyte antibodies, leading to massive absorption of hemoglobin by the renal tubules (hemoglobinuric nephrosis), producing blackwater fever. Complications of blackwater fever include renal failure, acute liver failure, and circulatory collapse. 

Complications of Falciparum malaria include:

  • Cerebral malaria
  • Algid malaria
  • Septicemic malaria
  • Blackwater fever
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute renal failure
  • Hypoglycemia (glucose <40 mg/dL)
  • Severe anemia (Hb <5 g/dL, PCV <15%)
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Shock
  • Bleeding disturbances

Other options:

Option A: Septicemic malaria is characterized by high continuous fever with the dissemination of the parasite to various organs, leading to multiorgan failure.

Option B: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D: Cerebral malaria is manifested by features of diffuse symmetric encephalopathy like headache, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, slowly lapsing into a coma.

questions.text:
Match the following Escherichia coli with its pathogenesis/virulence:

1. ETEC

 a. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

2. EIEC

 b. Invades intestinal mucosal cells

3. EHEC

 c. Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

4. EPEC

 d. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli
questions.solution:
Option C: 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d is correctly matched.

Escherichia coli strains Pathogenesis

ETEC- Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli

 Produces a heat stable toxin and causes activation of guanyl cyclase

EIEC- Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli

Invades intestinal mucosal cells

EHEC- Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli

 Produces a toxin against vascular endothelium cells

EPEC- Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli

Adheres to mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli

 

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

  1. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following enterotoxins:
    1. LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
    2. ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
      1. ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
      2. ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.
  2. Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invade interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and cause a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, detection of which can also be a diagnostic test.
  3. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  4. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of small intestine using EAF (EPEC adherence factor) and LEE (Locus of enterocyte membrane) and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells.
  5. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

questions.text: A young frequent traveler presented with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. A widely used tube agglutination test was ordered for this patient. Which of the following statements is true regarding this test?

choices.text: High titre value in a single  test is confirmative
Increase in titre after one week indicates anamnestic response
Agglutination titre depends on the stage of the disease
Early antibiotic treatment shows good agglutination response

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and the widely used tube agglutination test is the Widal test. In this test, the agglutination titer depends on the stage of the disease. 

Enteric fever (Typhoid fever) caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia, abdominal symptoms, headache, and malaise.

Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's sera. The antigens used in Widal's test include:
  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Paratyphoid O antigens cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen due to the sharing of factor 12, hence O antibody cannot differentiate between the Salmonella types.

Interpretation: 

  • The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease:
    • Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. 
    • The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.
  • The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
    • H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
    • The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 
  • The 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is highly significant as compared to a single high titer (Option A):
    • This is because, in persons who had a prior enteric fever, there is a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue), known as an anamnestic reaction.
    • Therefore, after a one-week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction. (Option B)
  • Cases treated early with antibiotics may show poor agglutinin response. (Option D)

questions.text: An immunologist has arranged a series of tubes for an experiment on precipitation reaction. The tubes contain equal amounts of antiserum, while increasing quantities of antigen are added from left to right. One of the middle tubes shows maximum precipitation. What is the phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube is called the prozone phenomenon. Here, antibodies are in excess compared to antigens leading to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

  • The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test (tubes on the left side in the question stem).
  • In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. (tube in the middle in question stem)
  • Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation (tubes on the right side in the question stem).


Prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Flocculation: It is a type of precipitation reaction in which the precipitate remains suspended as flocculus, instead of sedimenting.

questions.text: The faecal pollution of drinking water by coliform bacteria is assessed by multiple tube technique, which showed a positive result. Furthermore, another test is conducted to confirm the presence of coliform bacteria. Which of the following is not true regarding the second test?

choices.text: Gas in Durham's tube is considered positive for E.coli
Single strength MacConkey medium is used
Known as Eijkman test/ Differential coliform count
Gives the most probable number of coliforms present in the sample.

questions.solution:
The second test mentioned in the question stem is the differential coliform count or the Eijkman test. It is done to confirm that coliform bacilli detected in the presumptive test are in fact, E.coli. The most probable number (MPN) of coliforms present in the water sample (also known as Presumptive coliform count) is determined by the multiple tube technique (first test in the stem).

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test:

Methodology: Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37 degrees Celsius. These tubes are incubated at 44 degrees Celsius and examined after 24 hours.

Interpretation: 

  1. Tubes exhibiting gas in Durham's tubes are deemed to contain E.Coli.
  2. From the number of positive tubes obtained, the number of E.coli bacteria present in the water sample tested can be estimated by referring to Mc cardy's probability tables.
  3. The presence of E.coli can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilization.

questions.text: A patient complained of fever with a mild headache associated with difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever, headache, difficulty in swallowing, and throat examination findings of swollen glands, whitish membrane over tonsils, and gram stain showing a rod-shaped organism arranged in Chinese letter pattern is faucial diphtheria.

The condition is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. It is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

Image below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).  

Other options:

Option A: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium perfringens. It usually occurs when the organism invades the wound infections. Gram staining demonstrates gram-positive bacilli with spores as shown below.

Option B: Vincent's angina is a spirochetal infection and is a differential diagnosis of a membrane in the throat. It is caused by Leptotrichia buccalis (earlier known as Fusobacterium) and is demonstrated on gram stain as gram-negative curved rods with pointed ends. They appear as fusiform and spiral shaped bacilli as shown below.

Option D: Streptococcal pharyngitis usually doesn't cause membrane formation and appear as gram positive cocci in chains as shown in image below.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Identify the illumination system in the image below.
questions.solution:
Illumination system/ light source of microscope is marked as 2 in the image. It is a steady light source used in place of a mirror.

1 is objective lens. There are usually 3 or 4 objective lenses on a microscope. They almost always consist of 4X, 10X, 40X and 100X powers.

3 is coarse focusing knob. It moves the body tubes with its lenses.

4 is condenser. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light onto the specimen.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions are also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease:

It is a mild exanthematous fever that usually occurs in children, but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include -

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina - It is febrile vesicular pharyngitis. It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include -

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet: 

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus causes impetigo. It is characterized by sores around the mouth and the nose and typically forms a honey-colored scab. It is more commonly seen in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles.

The image given below shows impetigo.

Option C: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a T-lymphotropic human herpes virus transmitted via saliva. It may cause roseola infantum/ sixth disease/ exanthem subitum in infants and young children. Roseola infantum is primarily caused by HHV-6.

The image given below shows typical rashes in an infant with exanthem subitum.

Option D: Poxvirus causes molluscum contagiosum in children and young adults. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin. 

The image given below shows molluscum contagiosum lesions.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. He was prescribed ampicillin after which he developed a maculopapular rash. Which of the following is the standard diagnostic test for this condition?
questions.solution:
A young adult with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and development of a maculopapular rash after administration of ampicillin likely has infectious mononucleosis. The standard diagnostic test for this condition is the Paul Bunnell test, which is a heterophile antibody reaction test.

Infectious mononucleosis (IM), or kissing disease or glandular fever, is caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Patients present with fever, pharyngitis, bilateral symmetrical lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. A drug-induced rash may develop on using beta-lactam antibiotics. Large, atypical lymphocytes are seen in the peripheral blood of affected patients.

Paul-Bunnell test is a heterophile agglutination test used for the diagnosis of IM. It identifies the heterophile antibodies produced in IM that agglutinate erythrocytes of different animal species. These antibodies can be demonstrated by the end of the first week of illness, but are occasionally delayed until the third or fourth week and may persist for months. In this test, the inactivated serum of a patient is mixed with 1% suspension of sheep erythrocytes in serial dilutions. After incubation at 37°C for four hours the tubes are examined for agglutination. An agglutination titre of 100 or above is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.  

Other serological tests such as immunofluorescence and ELISA are employed to detect antibodies against EBV. The lgM antibody to VCA (virus capsid antigen) appears soon after primary infection and disappears in 1-2 weeks. It indicates primary infection. The IgG anti-VCA antibody persists throughout life and indicates past or recent infection. The new appearance of antibodies to the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) is a marker for primary infection.

Other options:

Option A: Cold agglutination test is used to detect primary atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma.

Option B: Weil-felix test is used for rickettsial infections.

Option D: Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosing leptospirosis.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases are likely to be associated with the antigen (marked by black arrow) shown in the image below?
  1. Toxic shock syndrome
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. B cell lymphoma
  4. Rheumatic fever
  5. Amoebiasis
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a superantigen. The diseases associated with superantigens are 

  1. Toxic shock syndrome
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. B cell lymphoma
  4. Rheumatic fever

Amoebiasis is caused by the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. Superantigens are usually viral or bacterial proteins. Hence, amoebiasis is not likely to be associated with superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of a T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity, i.e., they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

They are viral or bacterial protein toxins that activate the immune system by binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules and T-cell receptors (TCR) and stimulate large numbers of T cells to produce massive quantities of cytokines, in particular, IFN-γ.

 IFN-γ in turn activates macrophages to produce IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, all of which may contribute to a “cytokine storm” causing severe symptoms of shock and multiple organ failure.

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.
  • They are highly resistant to proteases and to denaturation by CD4+ T cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocapsid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.

Diseases associated with Superantigens:

  • Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS)
  • Streptococcal TSS
  • Food poisoning
  • Rheumatic fever
  • B cell lymphoma 
  • HIV and AIDS
  • Rabies
  • Tuberculosis
  • Psoriasis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: A 31-year-old man developed severe gastroenteritis with abdominal cramps, nausea, and vomiting. It was also associated with flushing, urticaria, palpitations, dizziness, and sweating. The symptoms began one hour after eating a smoked tuna fish sandwich. Which of the following is unlikely to be the etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case of gastroenteritis with flushing, urticaria, palpitations, dizziness, and sweating after consuming tuna fish is suggestive of scombroid poisoning, of which Vibrio parahaemolyticus is not a likely etiological agent.

Scombroid poisoning occurs after the consumption of fresh, canned, or smoked fish due to improper processing or storage. It is caused when the musculature of this dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, and Klebsiella species. There is consequent decarboxylation of L-histidine to histamine, histamine phosphate, and histamine hydrochloride. It is not an allergy to fish.

Symptoms begin 10-90 minutes after ingestion of the fish. They include flushing, rash, urticaria, palpitations, headache, dizziness, sweating, and burning of the mouth and throat, along with gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Bronchospasm, respiratory distress, and vasodilatory shock may occur in severe cases. 

Self-resolution of symptoms occurs within 8-12 hours.

Diagnosis is clinical, however scombroid poisoning is associated with elevated levels of histamine in the plasma or the presence of histamine metabolites in the urine. Diagnosis may also be confirmed by the measurement of histamine levels in the contaminated food.

Treatment:

  • Oral or iv antihistamines
  • IV fluids for hypotension  
  • Ondansetron or prochlorperazine for nausea and vomiting
  • For bronchospasm- An inhaled bronchodilator—or in rare, severe cases injected epinephrine may be used.

Note:

Shellfish poisoning is associated with a significant risk of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

questions.text: In a laboratory, a bacterium is seeded into a suitable liquid medium and incubated. Bacterial counts are made at intervals after inoculation and plotted in relation to time. A growth curve is obtained as shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the bacterial growth curve is not true?

choices.text: Adaptation to new environment occurs in phase A
Exotoxins are produced in phase C
Maximum size is in phase D
Cells stain uniformly in phase B

questions.solution:
The maximum size of the cell is towards the end of phase A, not D.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  1. Lag phase (Marked as A)
    • Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media.
    • There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
    • This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed
  2. Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B)
    • In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time.
    • Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  3. Stationary phase (Marked as C)
    • Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products.
    • It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die.
    • Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
    • Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
    • Cells are gram variable and show irregular staining due to the presence of intracellular storage granules.
  4. Phase of decline (Marked as D)
    • In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes.
    • Involution forms are common.

questions.text: The given life cycle is suggestive of which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle is of the hepatitis B virus. 

Steps: 

  • The infectious virion attaches to cells and uncoating occurs.
  • Cell enzymes in the hepatocytes convert dsDNA to covalently closed circular double-stranded DNA (cccDNA)
  • HBV mRNA and pre-genome RNA is synthesized using cccDNA as a template.
  • pre-genome RNA is encapsidated by packaging signal into new core particles.
  • These new core particles are templates for HBV reverse transcriptase.
  • Negative-strand DNA is synthesized by viral polymerase by reverse transcription. 
  • The cores bud from the pre-Golgi membranes, acquiring HBsAg-containing envelopes.
  • Once viral particles are assembled, they either exit the cell or cause reinfection of the same cell.

questions.text: An ICU patient with a central venous catheter developed sepsis. A bacterial skin commensal was found to be grown in the blood culture. Which of the following laboratory results is appropriate for the organism found in the blood culture?

choices.text: Catalase negative, coagulase negative, optochin sensitive
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive
Catalase negative, coagulase positive, bacitracin resistant

questions.solution:
Skin commensal responsible for catheter-related bloodstream infections are coagulase-negative Staphylococcus namely Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, and novobiocin sensitive.

Novobiocin sensitivity distinguishes S. epidermidis from S.saprophyticus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the equipment shown below?

choices.text: Geobacillus stearothermophilus acts as a control

questions.solution:
The above image shows an autoclave machine. It uses steam under pressure. Steam at atmospheric pressure is used in Koch or Arnold steamer.

Autoclave machine:

  • It is a method of sterilization by moist heat (steam under pressure)
  • High penetrative power
  • Temperature - 1210C for 15 min
  • Spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus act as a control
  • It is used to sterilize culture media, hospital linen, instruments, laboratory ware, and pharmaceutical products

Steam at atmospheric pressure (1000C) is used in Koch or Arnold steamer (image below). It is used to sterilize culture media which may decompose if exposed to higher temperatures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms with arching of his back, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. Microscopy of the specimen revealed a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus. Which of the following describes the characteristics of the spores produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario is Clostridium tetani. It is a gram-positive, anaerobic, rod-shaped bacillus with spores that are spherical and terminally located.

Clostridium tetani has spherical and terminal spores, giving it a drumstick appearance.

  • The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.
  • The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

Classification of Clostridium based on the shape and position of spores:

  • Central or Subterminal:  Clostridium bifermentans, Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani.

The incubation period of C. tetani ranges from 6-12 days. It produces an exotoxin tetanospasmin which causes muscle spasms usually involving the area of injury first and then the muscles of the jaw causing trismus or lockjaw. Gradually, other voluntary muscles become involved, resulting in tonic spasms. Any external stimulus can precipitate a tetanic generalized muscle spasm. The patient is conscious but may be in pain. Death usually results from respiratory paralysis.

The image given below shows spherical and terminal spores of C. tetani:

questions.text: A male patient presented with a chronic, progressively enlarging, indurated ulcer on his left hand for the past 1 month. He says that he takes bath daily in a pond. A diagnosis of Buruli ulcer is suspected. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is endemic to tropical wetlands.
It is caused by Mycobacterium marinum.
Rifampicin and streptomycin are used for treatment.

questions.solution:
Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma/ fish tank granuloma.

Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans - a fastidious, slow-growing bacterium. It is the third most common mycobacterial infection in humans, following tuberculosis and leprosy.

It is closely associated with tropical wetlands, and transmission occurs via mosquitoes and aquatic biting arthropods.

It is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue. It is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. 

The image given below shows a Buruli ulcer.

It can also manifest as a subcutaneous nodule, plaque, or an aggressive edematous infection of the soft tissue. Ulcers are usually seen on the legs or arms. They heal with disfiguring scars. Regional lymph nodes are not involved; no systemic invasion.
 
The smear from the edge of the ulcer shows large clumps of acid-fast bacilli.
 
Treatment:
  • Duration: 8 weeks
  • Antibiotics:
    • Rifampicin plus streptomycin
    • Rifampicin plus clarithromycin
    • Rifampicin plus moxifloxacin
  • Surgical debridement, skin grafting, wound care.

questions.text: A soldier infested with body louse comes with a 2-month history of recurrent fever with chills, headaches, and shin pain lasting for five days. The physician suspects it to be trench fever.  Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Also known as five day fever
Causative organism is associated with culture negative endocarditis

questions.solution:
Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana. It is an exclusively human disease and there is no known animal reservoir.

Trench fever is also known as a five-day fever. It occurred among the soldiers fighting in the trenches during World War. It is caused by Bartonella quintana and the vector is body louse.

Clinical features include sudden onset fever lasting for 5 days. It is associated with chills, headaches, malaise, shin pain, and restlessness.

Bartonella quintana is now frequently seen as the cause of culture-negative endocarditis in homeless individuals.

Bartonella henselae is another important organism in this genus. Cat is the animal reservoir for Bartonella henselae. It causes cat scratch disease, bacillary angiomatosis, and bacillary peliosis. In cat scratch disease, patients present with fever and lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. A biopsy of the affected lymph node will show the presence of rounded or stellate granuloma. Organisms can be seen with Warthin-Starry staining.

Bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis are mainly seen in HIV-infected or immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented with low-grade fever, loss of weight, and dry nocturnal cough for the past 6 months. Physical examination wheezing and crepitations on chest auscultation and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Eosinophil count- 10000/mm3. Serology revealed high levels of IgE and positive for filarial antibodies. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is directly due to lymphatic involvement
It is also known as Meyers Kouwenaar syndrome
Microfilaria cannot be demonstrated in blood
Diethylcarmazine is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young adult with pulmonary symptoms, pronounced blood eosinophilia, elevated serum IgE, and anti-filarial antibodies are suggestive of Occult Filariasis, in this case, Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia. It occurs as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction to micro-filarial antigens, not directly due to lymphatic involvement.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a hyperresponsive pulmonary syndrome in response to trapped microfilariae within the lung tissue. 

It is a manifestation of occult filariasis (also known as Meyer's-Kouwenaar syndrome). It occurs as a result of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to micro-filarial antigens, not directly due to lymphatic involvement.

More common in children and young adults in filarial endemic zones.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough
  • Weight loss, low-grade fever, lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL, leucocytosis
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities similar to miliary TB, increased broncho-vascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titers
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in the lungs and hence not found in blood

Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine(DEC)

Differntial Diagnosis:

  • Loffler syndrome
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
  • Churg strauss syndrome
  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Hypereosinophilic syndromes

questions.text: A patient presents with a cough with rusty sputum and fever for the past few weeks. She gives a history of recent travel to Japan and the consumption of raw crabs.  A complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: It is a food-borne trematode infection.
Eggs are coughed up in sputum.
Embryonated eggs are the infective form.
Praziquantel is the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke). All the given options are true about this condition, except that embryonated eggs are the infective form.

Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

P. westermani is a trematode. Transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae encyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Treatment: Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The following image shows the life cycle of P. westermani, the oriental lung fluke.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The life cycle shown in the above image is suggestive of leptospirosis. 

It is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonotic disease, with rats being the most well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: 

  • Acute leptospiremic phase- organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase- organism can be cultured from urine.

The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Most cases are asymptomatic but a few may present with severe manifestations. Clinical features include: 

  • High-grade fever
  • Hepatic dysfunction 
  • Renal impairment
  • Hemorrhages- gastrointestinal, pulmonary (most common), petechiae and purpura

The severe form is known as Weil's disease, with a triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. 

Treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: Infection with Opistorchis viverrini is associated with the increased risk of ___________ .
questions.solution:
Opistorchis viverrini leads to an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. 

Opistorchis viverrini, also known as southeast Asian liver fluke, is highly prevalent in Thailand. 

The life cycle and other features of Opisthorchis are the same as those of Clonorchis. Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae). The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.

The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs that are excreted in the feces. Upon reaching freshwater the eggs are ingested by snails, which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (rediae) and then into many free-swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst to form metacercariae under the scales of certain freshwater fish (second intermediate host) which are then ingested by humans.

In humans, it infects the common bile duct and gallbladder. Liver imaging shows a dilated biliary tract. It is a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

Diagnosis: Stool microscopy demonstrates eggs that do not float in saturated saline.

Treatment: Praziquantel is the drug of choice.

Clonorchis sinensis or Chinese liver fluke causes clonorchiasis. Clonorchis sinensis infection is endemic in south China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan due to a long tradition of consuming raw freshwater fish or shellfish. It is also associated with increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 Other options:

Option A: Hepatocellular carcinoma is associated with hepatitis B/C infection 

Option C: Gastric carcinoma is associated with Helicobacter pylori infection 

Option D: Schistosoma hematobium is a vesical blood fluke that mainly infects the urinary bladder and has a malignant potential causing Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for follow-up evaluation in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis is ______________ .
questions.solution:
Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) is the investigation of choice for follow-up evaluation in a patient who underwent therapy for syphilis. Failure of nontreponemal test titers to decrease fourfold within 12-24 months after therapy depending on the stage of syphilis (inadequate serologic response) might be indicative of treatment failure.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis - RPR or VDRL
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibodies to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy - RPR or VDRL
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test - FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA 
  • RPR - Rapid plasma reagin test
  • FTA-ABS - Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test 
  • TPHA - Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay 
  • EIA - Enzyme immunoassay
  • CIA - Chemiluminescence immunoassay

VDRL test is a slide flocculation test used widely for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

In this test, the serum is inactivated at 56°C for 30 minutes and a measured volume of serum is placed on a special cavity slide. The cardiolipin antigen after preparation is added to the serum sample on a slide and is rotated on a VDRL rotator for a specified period of 4 minutes. In a positive test, the cardiolipin antigen reacts with reagin antibodies present in the infected serum and forms visible clumps. In a negative test, cardiolipin continues to remain as uniform crystals in the serum.

The result of the test is reported as reactive, weak reactive, or nonreactive depending on the extent of the formation of the clumps. The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1–2 weeks after the appearance of the chancre. It is a highly sensitive test and the sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of the disease:-

  • The test is 60–75% sensitive in primary syphilis
  • The test is 100% sensitive in secondary syphilis
  • High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascular or cardiovascular complications.
  • The test is usually negative in the tertiary stage of syphilis
  • This test is negative in early primary syphilis, latent acquired syphilis, and late congenital syphilis

Other options:

Option A: Fluorescent treponema antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is an indirect immunofluorescence test used to detect specific treponemal antibodies. It is not available for routine testing as it is done only in suitably equipped labs.

Option C: Treponema pallidum immobilization (TPI) test detects the presence of treponemal antibodies in the serum. Similar to the FTA-ABS test, it is also not available for routine testing.

Option D: Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a type III hypersensitivity reaction, not type IV.

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are induced by sensitized T cells which on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Examples of type IV hypersensitivity reactions include sarcoidosis, leprosy, type I lepra reaction, tuberculosis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, contact dermatitis.

Type III hypersensitivity reactions: These reactions are induced by immune complexes which deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

Other examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, serum sickness, arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and type II lepra reaction.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presented to casualty with extensive burns as shown below.  Which of the following is the most likely etiology of infection in her?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely cause of infection in the case of a burn.

Pathogenesis

  • It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by means of diphtheria like exotoxin A and slime layer.
  • Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Diagnosis:

  • It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. 
  • Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Clinical features:

  • It is characterized by blue-green pus.
  • It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Note:

Aeruginosa is a Latin word meaning verdigris, which is the common name for a green pigment obtained through the application of acetic acid to copper plates.

The P. aeruginosa species is named so, as the blue-green pus caused by its infection resembles the green-pigment of verdigris.

questions.text:
A few cases of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection are reported in the surgical ward of your hospital. All of the following are important strategies in containing the spread of MRSA infection except:
  1. Proper hand hygiene
  2. Surveillance for nasal colonization among high-risk individuals
  3. Routine antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients hospitalized for more than 48 hours
  4. Contact isolation of MRSA - carriers or infection
  5. Aseptic management of skin lesion
questions.solution:
All of the above are important strategies in containing the spread of MRSA infection except option 3, that is, routine antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients hospitalized for more than 48 hours.

Routine antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated in all hospitalized patients for containing the spread of Methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. All the other measures given above are taken to control MRSA infection in a healthcare setting.

Measures to prevent and control the spread of MRSA infection include:

  1. Proper hand hygiene i.e. washing the hands before and after treating the patients is the most effective way to curb the spread of MRSA infections.
  2. Aseptic management of lesions.
  3. Active surveillance testing - screening for MRSA nasal carriers in high-risk patients such as those in ICUs in the hospital setting.
  4. Contact isolation of MRSA cases and carriers.
  5. Topical mupirocin treatment for nasal carriers (MRSA decolonization therapy).
  6. Avoiding antibiotic misuse in hospitals.
  7. Bundling - performing medical procedures in a sequence of prescribed steps - reduces the rate of nosocomial infection related to the procedure.
  8. Daily chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG) bathing in intensive care units (ICUs)
  9. Cleaning and decontamination of clinical areas.

The correct steps of hand washing are given below.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocysts containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites, as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian (one-celled) parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain–positive oocysts that are round, with 2 sporocysts, and each sporocyst having two sporozoites, as seen in the given image, are findings suggestive of Cyclospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, size of 8–12 μm, containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites which are variably acid-fast on staining.

The image given below shows the presence of four modified acid-fast stain-positive Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts in the field of view. Note that the staining is variable among the four oocysts.

Treatment of Cyclospora infection includes fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

Other options:

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst


The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.


The image given below shows the uniformly acid-fast, large, oval oocysts of Isospora belli.


Microspora spp. are unicellular, obligate intracellular parasites causing opportunistic illnesses, such as protracted diarrhea, in immunocompromised patients. They produce spores (not oocyst), which are the infective stage of microsporidia. Spores are 2–4 μm in size and oval to cylindrical in shape, with a polar filament. Spores are gram-positive and acid-fast.

questions.text:
A patient has been diagnosed with a fungal infection, for which fungal culture is ordered. Which of the following medium is/are used to cultivate the causative organism?
  1. Sabouraud dextrose agar
  2. Czapek-Dox medium
  3. Corn meal agar
  4. Brain heart infusion agar
questions.solution:
All the above are used as culture media in Mycology.

Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi.

It has a pH of 5.6 and contains glucose and modified peptone.

Fungal selective media are made by the addition of antibiotics like gentamicin or chloramphenicol to inhibit the contaminant bacteria and also cycloheximide to inhibit the growth of saprophytic fungi.

Other media used in mycology

  • Czapek-Dox medium
  • Bird seed agar
  • Corn meal agar
  • Brain heart infusion agar

questions.text:
Which of the following test(s) is/are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant ?
  1. Rideal-Walker test
  2. Chick Martin test
  3. Kelsey-Sykes test
  4. In-use test
questions.solution:
All of the above tests are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant.

The Rideal-Walker test helps in determining the phenol co-efficient (PC) which indicates the power of a disinfectant. A PC value of more than 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. It is only of historical value. St. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi were the organisms that were traditionally used for this test.

Chick Martin test: This is a modification of Rideal-Walker test in which the disinfectants acts in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions.

Kelsey-Sykes test (capacity test): It tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly. This is used now.

In-use test: It determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use. This is used now.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining of a sputum sample for diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Decolourising with iodine is not a step involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining. 

Steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen stain are:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolourised with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent part of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • Atleast 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

Grading of ZN- stained smears for AFB:-

Number of AFB per oil immersion field Grading Number of fields Result
>10 / field 3+ 20 Positive
1-10 / field 2+ 50 Positive
10-99 / 100 field 1+ 100 Positive
1-9 / 100 field Scanty 100 Positive
Nil AFB / 100 field   1000 Negative

Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

questions.text:
Choose the false statement(s) about triple sugar iron (TSI) media.
  1. A pink color indicates fermentation of sugars.
  2. Blackening of the media indicates H2S production.
  3. Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.
  4. It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.
questions.solution:
All the statements mentioned above are true about the triple sugar iron (TSI) medium except that a pink color indicates fermentation of sugars. Fermentation of sugars is indicated by yellow color on the TSI medium.

TSI medium is a composite medium and is used for the identification of isolates. It is convenient and economical as a single composite medium indicates different properties of the bacterium.

It indicates whether bacteria ferments glucose only or lactose and sucrose also, with/without gas formation. It also indicates H2S production.

  • If the slant and the butt turn yellow, all the sugars (glucose, lactose, sucrose) are fermented.
  • The blackening of the media indicates H2S production.
  • Bubbles in the butt indicate gas production.

It facilitates the preliminary identification of gram-negative bacilli.

Examples of composite media:

  1. TSI medium
  2. Bile esculin medium - differentiates between Enterococcus (group D) and other streptococci

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of sudden-onset fever for the past 2 months. She says that the fever lasts for 3-4 days, subsides for a few days, and recurs again. Clinical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly with mild tenderness. The image below shows the vector responsible for transmitting this infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis suggest epidemic relapsing fever. It is caused by the bacteria Borrelia recurrentis. 

Relapsing fever is an arthropod-borne infection due to Borrelia species. It can be of two types: 

  • Louse-borne or epidemic relapsing fever acquired from head or body louse and caused by Borrelia recurrentis
  • Tick-borne or endemic relapsing fever acquired from soft ticks. It is caused by Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia duttonii, and Borrelia parkeri (options A, C, and D)

Patients with relapsing fever present with sudden onset of fever that persists for 3–5 days and then subsides. The afebrile period lasts 4–10 days and is followed by a second attack of fever, chills, rigors, intense headache, and malaise.

During the febrile stages, organisms are present in the blood. During the afebrile periods, they are absent. It may be associated with jaundice and hemorrhages.

Treatment of relapsing fever includes tetracycline, chloramphenicol, penicillin, and erythromycin.

  Epidemic relapsing fever Endemic relapsing fever
Vector Body louse, Pediculus humanus corporis Soft tick
Transmission Crushing or rubbing the lice on an abraded skin Bite of ticks or their discharges
Causative bacteria Borrelia recurrentis Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia duttonii, and Borrelia parkeri
Location Epidemics occur in places like overcrowding, poverty,  wars, and jails Endemic areas inhabited by infected soft ticks
Clinical features A more severe form of relapsing fever A milder form of relapsing fever with high recurrence

 
The image given below shows a soft tick.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A bacteriologist conducts the following experiment in a blood agar from the sputum sample of a pneumonia patient. He observes a particular phenomenon from the experiment. Choose the false statement regarding this phenomenon.

choices.text: S. aureus streaked in the centre
It is exhibited by H. Influenzae

questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism, which is dependant on the V factor (not factor X). It is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when it is incubated on blood agar along with a streak of Staphylococcus aureus. 

Factor V produced by Staphylococcus aureus helps in the growth of Haemophilus. Haemophilus colonies will be larger and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus aureus. This is because the V factor is present in high concentrations near the streak. The Hemophilus colonies become progressively smaller further away from the streak because V factor concentration becomes less. 

This phenomenon is known as satellitism. It is shown in the below image.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with low-grade fever and a skin lesion as shown below.  He had a  history of recent travel to North America.  Chest X-Ray reveals consolidation in the right lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 37°C shows thick-walled, large (7-20 µ), round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with pulmonary and cutaneous involvement along with a history of travel to North America and the characteristic culture findings suggests the diagnosis of blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermitidis. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and so is also called North American Blastomycosis. The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in the soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  1. Pulmonary disease:
    • Presents with cough, sputum production, chest pain, and fever
    • Hilar lymphadenopathy may be present
    • Focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation may occur.
    • Resembles TB and Histoplasmosis 
  2. Cutaneous disease:
    • Involvement of face and exposed parts of the skin
    • Skin lesion: ulcerated verrucous granulomas with an advancing border and central scarring. The border is filled with microabscesses and has a sharp, sloping edge. (image in stem)
  3. Disseminated disease:
    • Multiple skin lesions are the most common presentation
    • Highly fatal 
    • Genitourinary tract (especially prostate) is frequently involved
    • Bone involvement resembles chronic osteomyelitis.
It can be diagnosed based on culture findings. Characteristic findings include the presence of thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud when cultured at 37°C. (figure of 8 appearance)

Treatment:

  • Localized mild/moderate disease - Itraconazole (6 months)
  • Disseminated/ severe disease - Amphotericin B

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggests that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Zeimann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae has the lowest degree of parasitization. 

P.vivax has ring forms that resemble P.malariae but they are thinner and less intensely stained. Erythrocytes are enlarged, and pale with Schuffner's dots. 

In P.ovale, the infected erythrocytes are slightly enlarged and oval shape with fimbriated margins. Prominent Schuffner's dots are present on the erythropcyte. 

Erythrocyte in P.falciparum initially will show marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shoes a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.
