questions.text: Working as a duty doctor in a COVID care centre, you were trained on sanitation techniques, donning, doffing of PPE and other preventive measures to reduce the incidence of disease. You were recommended to use alcohol-based hand rubs to curtail the spread of COVID-19 infection. The microbiological basis for the same would be?

choices.text: COVID-19 virus has a lipid envelope
COVID-19 virus has a glycoprotein capsid

questions.solution:
Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred because COVID 19 virus has a lipid envelope that contributes to its susceptibility to lipid solvents. 

Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses. Alcohol, especially ethanol present in the hand rubs, dissolves the lipid envelope and denatures the proteins present. This leads to membrane disruption and inhibition of the metabolism, as depicted below:

The Coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA which is, in fact, the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120 - 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. They have club-shaped or petal-shaped projections that are widely spaced on the outer surface of the envelope, suggestive of a solar corona.

The virus has spike proteins - S1 and S2 which are responsible for the host specificity, faster spread of the disease, and make it highly susceptible to mutations. While S1 protein is involved in the attachment of the virus with the ACE-2 receptor, S2 protein is involved in virus-host cell fusion. 

The virus responsible for the pandemic that started in 2019 is named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19). 

SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, and is considered to be a new member of the genus Betacoronavirus.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of soft tissue swelling on the right jaw. He had a history of trauma to the area. On examination, a discharging sinus was found (seen below). On microscopic examination of the pus, sulfur granules were found in the exudate. Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding this condition?
  1. Cervicofacial area is the most common site of infection.
  2. Sulfur granules are purely composed of dead host tissues.
  3. Bacterial colonies on agar have a molar tooth appearance.
  4. Penicillin is the drug of choice.
questions.solution:
This is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. Statements 1, 3, and 4 are true about it.
It presents as a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules.

It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive device.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance)
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

Treatment:

  • Duration of therapy: 6-12 months.
  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice.
  • Other drugs that can be used: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin, Tetracycline, Doxycycline, Clindamycin, Minocycline.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of the Actinomyces colonies.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

 

The given image shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis:

questions.text:
A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have a Herpes simplex virus infection. Choose the correct sequence of steps done in PCR.
  1. DNA extraction
  2. Denaturation
  3. Annealing
  4. Extension
questions.solution:
Option D (1-2-3-4) is correct. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) involves the following steps: DNA extraction from the organism, DNA amplification (denaturation, annealing, extension), and gel electrophoresis of the amplified product.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes).

Steps:

  1. DNA extraction from the organism
  2. Amplification of the extracted DNA in a thermocycler where it is subjected to repeated cycles. Each cycle has three steps:
    1. Denaturation - heating to separate double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) into two separate strands (ssDNA)
    2. Annealing - addition of primer which anneals or attaches to the target ssDNA
    3. Extension - addition of free nucleotides to the growing end of the primer by DNA polymerase 
  3. Gel electrophoresis of the amplified product

Types of PCR:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. 

The image below shows the various ingredients involved in PCR.

questions.text: An elderly man was admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever and night sweats along with productive cough. He also mentions that he has lost weight. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. His sputum sample was collected for Modified acid-fast stain and revealed the following. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The organism shown in the image is the Nocardia asteroides. They are modified acid-fast positive and appear as branching, filamentous rods. Patients with nocardiosis usually present with symptoms mimicking tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, night sweats.  

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis is the main presentation and usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.

Treatment- Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option A - Mycobacteria tuberculosis is acid-fast but does not have branching filaments.

Option B - Actinomyces israelii is not acid-fast.

Option C - Corynebacterium diphtheriae is not acid-fast.

Image above: Gram-positive Corynebacterium diphtheriae, stained using the methylene blue technique

Image above: Mycobacterium tuberculosis stained with Ziehl–Neelsen stain

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy was administered a 'transfer factor' containing competent lymphocytes to improve his immunity. Which of the following types of immunity is offered by this treatment?
questions.solution:
The administration of the transfer factor provides adoptive immunity, which is a special type of immunity.

Adoptive immunity is immunity in which immunologically competent lymphocytes are injected. The transfer factor is composed of these immunologically competent lymphocytes. It can passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

Adoptive immunity is different from adaptive immunity. 

Adaptive immunity/ active immunity is the resistance developed by an individual as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is known as adaptive immunity as it represents the adaptive response of the host to a specific pathogen or another antigen.

Types of immunity: 

  • Natural active immunity: It results from either a clinical or an inapparent infection by a microbe. For e.g, A person who has recovered from an attack of measles develops natural active immunity against measles.
  • Artificial active immunity: It is the resistance induced by vaccines which are preparations of killed or attenuated microorganisms or their products. For e.g, the BCG vaccine induces immunity against TB
  • Natural passive immunity: It is the immunity passively transferred from mother to baby. In human infants, maternal antibodies are transmitted predominantly through the placenta, while in animals such as pigs, the transfer of antibodies occurs mainly through the colostrum. The human colostrum is also rich in lgA antibodies and gives protection to the neonate
  • Artificial passive immunity: It is the resistance passively transferred to a recipient by the administration of antibodies. Hyperimmune sera of animal or human origin, convalescent sera, pooled human immunoglobulin are used for this purpose. For e.g, anti-tetanus serum, anti-diphtherial serum.
  • Combined immunization: Sometimes a combination of the active and passive methods of immunization is used; Antisera and vaccine are given at the same time. For e.g, in the protection of a non-immune individual with a tetanus-prone wound, tetanus immunoglogulin (TIG) is injected in one arm, with a full course of tetanus toxoid in the other. This is followed by full course of tetanus toxoid vaccine. TIG provides the protection necessary till active immunity is able to take effect.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio?
questions.solution:
The disruption of zonula occludens is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae.

Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is an enterotoxin elaborated by Vibrio cholerae that increases intestinal permeability by interacting with a mammalian cell receptor with subsequent activation of intracellular signaling leading to the disassembly of the intercellular tight junctions.

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
  • A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate.
  • The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
  • All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
Match the following organisms with their respective transport media.
Bacteria Transport Media
 1. Neisseria i. Pike’s media

2. Vibrio cholera

ii. Venkatraman–Ramakrishnan medium
 3. Streptococcus  iii. Stuart media
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Bacteria Transport media
1. Neisseria iii. Stuart media

2. Vibrio cholera

ii. Venkatraman–Ramakrishnan medium
 3. Streptococcus i. Pike’s media

 

Transport media:

  1. Pike's medium is a blood agar containing 1 in 1,000,000 crystal violet and 1 in 16,000 sodium azide. It is used as transport media for Streptococcus.
  2. Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium, which prevents microbial proliferation. It is composed of sodium glycerophosphate, sodium thioglycollate, calcium chloride, methylene blue, and agar.
  3. Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium is prepared by dissolving 20 g crude sea salt and 5 g peptone in one liter of distilled water and adjusting the pH to 8.6- 8.8. It is dispensed in screw-capped bottles in quantities of 10-15 ml. About 1-3 ml of the stool must be added to each bottle. It is used to transport Vibrio cholerae.
  4. Cary-Blair medium is a buffered solution of sodium chloride, sodium thioglycollate, disodium phosphate, and calcium chloride at a pH of 8.4. It is a suitable transport medium for Salmonella, Shigella, and Vibrios.
  5. Autoclaved seawater serves as a holding medium for Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman had gone on a trek in the Amazon rainforest. A month later she presented with the following painful and pruritic lesion. Her systemic examination was normal. Which of the following organisms is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The image showing itchy and painful serpiginous skin lesions in the absence of systemic features is suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans (creeping eruption or ground itch). This is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they are unable to penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry and serpiginous tracks in the epidermis. The symptoms appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily.

Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features. The treatment includes thiabendazole topical application, albendazole 400mg/day X 3 days or ivermectin 200mcg/kg single dose stat.

The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:

  Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans
Tissue involved Skin Various organs of the body like the liver, lungs, and eyes
Infecting Organism Mostly by non-human nematodes Mostly by non-human nematodes (acquired mainly from dogs and cats)
Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs
Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high
Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole Diethylcarbamazine and prednisolone

Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised, hyper-infestation syndrome occurs with paralytic ileus and secondary Gram-negative sepsis.
